Comment: Pillsbury intends to drive his KBP forward, so he doesn't yet move his KN.
Pillsbury intends to drive his KBP forward, so he doesn't yet move his KN.
Pillsbury intends to drive his KBP forward, so he doesn't yet move his KN.
The amateur responds with symmetry, unsure of how to handle Pillsbury's unusual opening.
In effect, a delayed King's Gambit.
Declining the gambit, a move that even by a grandmaster leads to equality at best. The proper way to refute the King's Gambit is to accept the Pawn and return it later for a positional advantage.
Now that his KBP is advanced, Pillsbury can develop this Knight.
A wasted move. The pin was no real threat.
Apparently the amateur is unaware of the Legal pitfall.
The junction point. The correct reply is 6... PxP!
This move loses the game, either quickly or slowly.
Black can lose slowly by conceding a piece: 7... PxN 8 QxB, and White has a long but easy win with his material advantage.
Black chooses to die quickly. Mate in 2 follows.
A classic trap, well executed by Pillsbury.
